4. 25 Motivation to sharing a cluster ‚Ä¢ We live in the high performance computing (HPC) era! ‚Ä¢ There is no single framework that optimal for all applications. ‚Ä¢ We want to run multiple frameworks in a single cluster. ‚Ä¢ Sharing improves cluster utilization. ‚Ä¢ Allows applications to share access to large datasets. ‚Ä¢ May be too costly to replicate across distinct clusters! October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures Introduction Architecture Implementation Design pros & ‚Ä¶ Reversing Mesos Conclusion ÔÅä ÔÅå 4

5. 25 Common solutions for sharing a cluster 1. Statically partition the cluster and run one framework per partition. 2. Allocate a set of VMs to each framework. ‚Ä¢ Disadvantages: ‚Ä¢ No high utilization, ‚Ä¢ No efficient data sharing. ‚Ä¢ Better solution: ‚Ä¢ Dynamic fine-grained sharing ÔÉ†Mesos! 7. 25 Mesos design decisions ‚Ä¢ Small microkernel-like core ‚Ä¢ Implements fine-grained sharing ‚Ä¢ Allocation at the level of tasks within a job ‚Ä¢ High-availability and fault-tolerance ‚Ä¢ Simple and scalable application-controlled scheduling mechanism. 10. 25 Apache Mesos architecture: Resource Offer ‚Ä¢ The master implements Ô¨Åne-grained sharing across frameworks using resource offers. ‚Ä¢ Each Resource Offer is a list of free resources on multiple slaves. ‚Ä¢ The master decides how many resources to offer to each framework according to an organizational policy. ‚Ä¢ Mesos lets organizations deÔ¨Åne their own policies via a pluggable allocation module. Introduction Architecture Implementation Design pros & ‚Ä¶ Reversing Mesos Conclusion October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures 10

11. 25 Apache Mesos architecture: Resource Offer ‚Ä¢ Each framework running on Mesos consists of two components: ‚Ä¢ A scheduler that registers with the master to be offered resources. ‚Ä¢ An executor process that is launched on slave nodes to run the framework‚Äôs tasks. ‚Ä¢ Frameworks‚Äô schedulers select which of the offered resources to use. 28. 25 Terminology ‚Ä¢ Cluster ‚Ä¢ A collection of distributed machines that collaborate to present a single integrated computing resource to the user. ‚Ä¢ Node ‚Ä¢ Each computing element (single machine itself) within cluster. ‚Ä¢ Framework ‚Ä¢ A software system that manages and executes one or more jobs on a cluster. Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +3

29. 25 Terminology ‚Ä¢ Job ‚Ä¢ A unit of work run on the cluster nodes. ‚Ä¢ Slot ‚Ä¢ Nodes are subdivided into ‚Äúslots‚Äù. ‚Ä¢ (In some framework such as Hadoop and Dryad) ‚Ä¢ Task ‚Ä¢ Jobs are composed of short tasks that are matched to slots. ‚Ä¢ (In some framework such as Hadoop and Dryad) Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +4

30. 25 Terminology ‚Ä¢ Elastic framework ‚Ä¢ Can scale its resources up and down during execution tasks (dynamically). ‚Ä¢ Such as Hadoop and Dryad. ‚Ä¢ Rigid framework ‚Ä¢ Can start running its jobs only after it has acquired a Ô¨Åxed quantity of resources. ‚Ä¢ Can not scale (up/down) dynamically. ‚Ä¢ Such as MPI. Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +5

31. 25 Goals to Design Mesos ‚Ä¢ High utilization ‚Ä¢ Efficient data sharing ‚Ä¢ Support diverse frameworks (current and future) ‚Ä¢ Scalability to 10,000‚Äôs of nodes ‚Ä¢ Reliability in face of failures (robust to failures) Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +6

32. 25 Background ‚Ä¢ Diverse array of cluster computing frameworks: ‚Ä¢ Hadoop/ Map-Reduce (multi-terabyte data-sets) ‚Ä¢ Dryad (machine learning) ‚Ä¢ Pregel (graph computation) ‚Ä¢ MPI ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¶ Dryad Pregel Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +7

33. 25 Problem ‚Ä¢ Rapid innovation in cluster computing frameworks. ÔÉòThere is no single framework that optimal for all applications. ÔÉòClusters typically run single framework at a time. Backup slides October 2018 Apache Mesos - Morteza Zakeri - Software Architectures +8

34. 25 Problem ‚Ä¢ Hadoop data warehouse at Facebook: ‚Ä¢ Include 2000-node Hadoop cluster, ‚Ä¢ Uses a fair scheduler for Hadoop, ‚Ä¢ Takes advantage of the Ô¨Åne-grained nature of the workload, ‚Ä¢ Allocate resources at the level of tasks and to optimize data locality. ‚Üì ‚Ä¢ This cluster can only run Hadoop jobs! ‚Ä¢ Can it run an MPI program efficiently?
